story:
Making it Count

GU is a 13 year old webcomic, born of MMO guild chat, that grew into an industry wide love letter. And where viewer numbers are still pretty high, ad revenue is terrible. I'd like to be able to do the comics without focussing on that aspect of the "business". 

Needs and Wants

I've drilled it down to ask for as little as possible. $13,500 minus the fees and such won't be enough to completely meet the need, it will ease the situation a bit and let me scrap the tower ad from the site. Meeting stretch goals will allow us to peel other ads off the site as well. We'll talk about that later though.

Ads Suck

Though the total ad value on my site is worth far more than $12,000 per position for an entire year, that's all I need to get buy. And if I can get away from dependence on Ad revenue I can focus more on the comic, commissions, and playing games which is what the site is all about.

So, if we hit the first $13,500, we'll pull the 160x600 tower add off of the site. At the first stretch goal we'll take down the 728x90 leaderboard ad. At the second we'll tear down the last vesitages of the Ad State and proclaim our freedom from it's regime for a full year. 

No Cash? No Problem!

If you don't have any cash on hand, don't worry. Trust me; I understand. But please feel free to tell other people about the project. Facebook, Twitter, IndieGoGo's share tools, emails to freinds, family and guild mates, forums posts, whatever you feel comfortable with.

 

Stretch Goals

As I mentioned above if we hit the $13,500 goal we'll take the primary ad position (160x600) off of the GU site entirely. But there's more work that can be done.

$27,000 - Remove the Leaderboard Ad

If I'm honest, I'd like to see this 728x90 ad unit go first. But from the standpoint of redesigning the website (which I'm currently in the process of doing) it's easier to have this location be the second size to come down.

$40,500 - Remove the Ad Block

The 300x250 Ad Block is the most innocuous of the bunch. It's a natural fit for removal last because it's so easy to move and code around.

$45,000 - No Commission Come-Ons

I know there will be readers that will want commissions no matter what. But I also know that there are some readers who don't like seeing the Artist For Sale! and GU Commissions banners. So if we hit this stretch, I will make every effort to avoid hawking my artistic wares. The only exception would be in the case of an unforseen emergency.

$60,000 - Bonus Comics!

If by some miracle we manage to hit $60,000 I will produce -AT LEAST- 2 bonus, non-GU comics per month, for a year, based on my group's table top gaming experiences. These comics will also be provided ad free.

$75K - ???

I'll tell you about this exciting stretch goal if we hit $40,500 and strip all ads off the site.

FAQ

I've got more questions, where can I send them? indiegogo@gucomics.com

What is the Fancast? The Fancast is a part of the GU Forums where I post artwork that's not readily available elsewhere on the site. I'm hoping that I willl get to ad even more Fancast Content if the Project funds and I don't have to worry about dealing with ad revenue.

About the Random Panel Reward Perk? The random selection will be made from the available panels ($25 and up), after the Pick-A-Panel funders make their choices. You can see what's currently available here: http://www.gucomics.com/archives/pricelist.php

Quick-Sketch Perk: can I pick the subject matter? Requests are welcomed, but please keep it to just a few words. Otherwise the quick sketch is not so quick. Please also note: These will not be digitally produced. There aren't many my tangible sketches floating around.

Can fans buy a Corporate Sponsorship for a game they like? Yes, if a group of players got together to buy a "corporate sponsor"ship, I would certainly focus on their game of choice for a month. A couple of things to note though: 1) It would still have to be a game that I could personally endorse and play. 2) I would not be able to put that game's ads into my ad inventory without the game developer's permission.

What happens if you don't hit $13,500? Depending on your perk level you will be given access to the Fancast for the listed amount of time. If we manage to bring in $8000 or more I will add a login to the main GU site so that Fancast members still receive an ad free GU.

What if you go over $75K? Yeah this is highly unlikely. Honestly I'd be surprised is we even hit the goal. But, just in case, I have plans for up to $200K. If we get anywhere near $75, I will dream up more stretch goals.

When will the ad free site go live? Immediately. Because we're using Flex Funding, as soon as I get the email from Indiegogo that says we hit our goal, I'll go in and pull the 160x600 ad from the site's code. Same with each of the other ad removal stretch goals.

Why are the delivery dates so many months away? Really it's just giving myself plenty of buffer time JUUUST incase. I expect everything will be finished and out the door much sooner than the "estimated delivery date".

Didn't Penny Arcade already do this? Yup.

So, if we hit the first $13,500, we'll pull the 160x600 tower add off of the site. At the first stretch goal we'll take down the 728x90 leaderboard ad. At the second we'll tear down the last vesitages of the Ad State and proclaim our freedom from it's regime for a full year. 
No Cash? No Problem!


If you don't have any cash on hand, don't worry. Trust me; I understand. But please feel free to tell other people about the project. Facebook, Twitter, IndieGoGo's share tools, emails to freinds, family and guild mates, forums posts, whatever you feel comfortable with.
 

Stretch Goals
As I mentioned above if we hit the $13,500 goal we'll take the primary ad position (160x600) off of the GU site entirely. But there's more work that can be done.
$27,000 - Remove the Leaderboard Ad
If I'm honest, I'd like to see this 728x90 ad unit go first. But from the standpoint of redesigning the website (which I'm currently in the process of doing) it's easier to have this location be the second size to come down.
$40,500 - Remove the Ad Block
The 300x250 Ad Block is the most innocuous of the bunch. It's a natural fit for removal last because it's so easy to move and code around.
$45,000 - No Commission Come-Ons
I know there will be readers that will want commissions no matter what. But I also know that there are some readers who don't like seeing the Artist For Sale! and GU Commissions banners. So if we hit this stretch, I will make every effort to avoid hawking my artistic wares. The only exception would be in the case of an unforseen emergency.
$60,000 - Bonus Comics!
If by some miracle we manage to hit $60,000 I will produce -AT LEAST- 2 bonus, non-GU comics per month, for a year, based on my group's table top gaming experiences. These comics will also be provided ad free.
$75K - ???
I'll tell you about this exciting stretch goal if we hit $40,500 and strip all ads off the site.

FAQ
I've got more questions, where can I send them? indiegogo@gucomics.com
What is the Fancast? The Fancast is a part of the GU Forums where I post artwork that's not readily available elsewhere on the site. I'm hoping that I willl get to ad even more Fancast Content if the Project funds and I don't have to worry about dealing with ad revenue.
About the Random Panel Reward Perk? The random selection will be made from the available panels ($25 and up), after the Pick-A-Panel funders make their choices. You can see what's currently available here: http://www.gucomics.com/archives/pricelist.php
Quick-Sketch Perk: can I pick the subject matter? Requests are welcomed, but please keep it to just a few words. Otherwise the quick sketch is not so quick. Please also note: These will not be digitally produced. There aren't many my tangible sketches floating around.Can fans buy a Corporate Sponsorship for a game they like? Yes, if a group of players got together to buy a "corporate sponsor"ship, I would certainly focus on their game of choice for a month. A couple of things to note though: 1) It would still have to be a game that I could personally endorse and play. 2) I would not be able to put that game's ads into my ad inventory without the game developer's permission.
What happens if you don't hit $13,500? Depending on your perk level you will be given access to the Fancast for the listed amount of time. If we manage to bring in $8000 or more I will add a login to the main GU site so that Fancast members still receive an ad free GU.
What if you go over $75K? Yeah this is highly unlikely. Honestly I'd be surprised is we even hit the goal. But, just in case, I have plans for up to $200K. If we get anywhere near $75, I will dream up more stretch goals.
When will the ad free site go live? Immediately. Because we're using Flex Funding, as soon as I get the email from Indiegogo that says we hit our goal, I'll go in and pull the 160x600 ad from the site's code. Same with each of the other ad removal stretch goals.
Why are the delivery dates so many months away? Really it's just giving myself plenty of buffer time JUUUST incase. I expect everything will be finished and out the door much sooner than the "estimated delivery date".
Didn't Penny Arcade already do this? Yup.

story:
Now available for download and streaming everywhere via Vimeo On Demand:

https://vimeo.com/ondemand/gtgselric


Also available on DVD via Amazon.com: http://amzn.com/B01K0BS35W

 

About the Creators

A graduate of the University of Cincinnati with a degree in painting, P. Craig Russell has run the gamut in comics. After establishing a name for himself at Marvel on Killraven and Dr. Strange, he went on to become one of the pioneers in opening new vistas for this underestimated field with, among other works, adaptations of operas by Mozart (The Magic Flute), Strauss (Salome) and Wagner (The Ring of the Nibelung). His more recent work includes comic book adaptations of Neil Gaiman’s Coraline and The Graveyard Book.

Wayne Alan Harold is an independent filmmaker and publisher who lives in Northeast Ohio. Harold recently edited and published Russell’s Sketchbook Archives, a coffee table book style hardcover art book. He is currently overseeing the restoration of the original art for a number of the artist’s groundbreaking 80s projects, including graphic novel adaptations of Ariane & Bluebeard and The Jungle Book.


About The Video

 

A feature-length instructional video featuring master artist P. Craig Russell teaching the art of comic-book storytelling by examining sequences from "The Dreaming City" and "While the Gods Laugh." We used Russell's recently restored full-color art for both projects for the insert shots. Running time is approximately 45 mins.

 

The Nine Pages That Are Examined

story:
Story

An illegal genetic research lab was set up on a remote planet. But after the corporation in charge came under investigation by officials on Earth, all communications were cut off and the colonist abandoned, leaving them marooned on a world with harsh conditions and limited natural resources.

Seventy years later, the outlaw Sunday Childs, born into this world, struggles to survive the apocalyptic landscape populated by warring factions and escaped genetic experiments.  Sunday's luck will change for the better or the worse when she is sent on an assassination mission by the planet's ancient ruler know as the Mother.

What Are You Backing

  • A post-apocalyptic sci-fi comic
  • Second issue in a five issue mini series
  • The comic is 32 pages

Preview

Read the first 10 pages of issue 1

Creators

Joshua Metzger

Writes the crime comics Punch Drunk (Arcana Comics),  Metzger and Pawlak Presents: Villain (Evoluzione Publishing) and Le Fay (No Sleep).

Carlos Nieto

Carlos Nieto is a comic artist and illustrator from Madrid, Spain. He graduated in Fine Arts from the Complutense University of Madrid. After some first experiences in the world of comics with several web-comics and fanzines, he published with a national publisher his first creator-owned comic-book called ‘Fated’. His international professional career in comic-books started with ‘Star Trek’ series for IDW Publishing. Since then, he have worked for several international publishers of different countries.

Besides that, Carlos works for advertising illustrations, character designs and and many more projects involved with drawing, illustration and sequential art process.

Finally, Carlos Nieto is a highly creative professional who has solid, clean and clear storytelling with excellent illustration skills. He is passionate about telling stories and he also enjoys working with other professional to create them!

Luis Antonio Delgado

Luis Antonio Delgado, colorist for the fan favorite series, Ghostbusters, was born in Mexico City in 1982, he discovered comic books at the age of eight with the “Dark Night over Metroplois” story, and never looked back. After studying Graphic Design in Mexico, he went to Halifax, Nova Scotia and studied Illustration before meeting his mentor Raúl Cruz back in Mexico in 2005. He followed Raúl’s steps and in 2007 went to San Diego Comic Con and met IDW editor, Tom Waltz. After months of uncertainty, he finally got the long awaited email that changed his life, Tom Waltz offered him a project coloring a 12-page story in Gene Simmons House of Horrors #3. Thirteen years, over a 100 comic books and half a dozen board games later he has worked on properties such as Ghostbusters, TMNT, Star Wars, Transformers, My Little Pony, Spider-Man, Batman, Superman, GI JOE, Archie, Sonic, Mega Man, Star Trek and more.

story:
Short Summary

The first stories of fantastic creatures and people with god-like abilities first surfaced in Greece in the 8th century BC.  We are all aware of these Greek Gods and their stories.  What if I told you these stories where inspired by some real-life events?  1,500 years prior to the first accounts of the Greek Gods, the book of Genesis records in chapter 6 a peculiar event.  It recounts "the sons of God" coming to Earth and looking upon the daughters of men and enjoying what they see.  These angels began to produce offspring with human women and the outcome was an angel/human hybrid called the Nephilim.  These Nephilim have their own stories and lore which is all very similar to the stories of the Greek Gods.  As it turns out, these tales of Zeus and Poseidon have some roots in reality.  Like any good story, there is a bit of truth sprinkled with fiction.  

Now what if the real-life inspiration for the Greek Gods, the Nephilim, left behind a little bit of their DNA and over the years it has been lying dormant in men and women walking the streets today like a recessive trait just waiting to wake up?  Rather than having a recessive trait that makes you a ginger, or have blue eyes, you could have a recessive traits that gives you the ability to lift buildings, or control time itself!

That is exactly what happens in Hybrids (angel/human hybrids) The Sons of Gods (ancestors of the Greek Gods).  Seemingly out of nowhere people begin to develop great abilities like the ancient Greek Gods when all of a sudden, these "hybrids" begin to vanish!  Our story follows a small band of heroes desperately trying to stop these traffickers from taking anymore hybrids after their own loved ones have been taken.  They are trying to learn who is taking them, where are they taking them, and possibly most disturbing, WHY ARE THEY TAKING THEM?:

  • My name is Luke Stone and I am the writer and artist behind this series.  For the past 10 years I have worked to research and develop this story to not only offer an interesting concept, but to build a plot that helps develop these amazing characters. I also attempt to offer a fresh perspective to matters of faith and humanity within the story. 
  • This campaign is designed to help people get up to speed with Hybrids as it nears the end of its first 5 issue arc.  Issue 4 begins to truly form the world around our characters and we begin to see some deeply human traits in these god-like beings.  You even get a chance to see how some of those "normal" humans can have a tenacity and passion that surpasses even the strongest Titan!
  • Your contribution will help me bring the rest of this story to comic fans all over.  The cost of producing a book like this is not cheap and further more, the cost of printing and marketing can overwhelm the indie artist quickly.  With your help, I will be able to take this book to the next level!  We will print enough copies to seek widespread distribution and hopefully have enough left to fully produce issue 5 which concludes the first of 3 planned arcs of Hybrids: The Sons of Gods.

Thank you for your consideration today!  

 

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

If you are still with me, I want to give some more details to what exactly we are trying to do.:

Printing/Sales - Currently, Hybrids is printed in low runs and sold primarily at conventions and through the Star Cross Comics website.  We aim to get a larger print run of all 4 current issues and find a more wide spread distribution of the books to brick and mortar retailers.  We are seeking a few methods right now including direct to store distribution through Star Cross and possibly a submission to DCD.

We are offering to you some very exclusive items that will only be available in the current form for a limited time.  Issues 1-2 will get a complete overhaul of covers and some minor content changes. All 4 issues will receive a new variant. 

 

Additional Insight

Something you may not know about me is that I am a full-time pastor in Jacksonville.  I have alway loved comics and even submitted my first art samples to Marvel at age 14!  They said no...  

I have also wanted to find a way to allow my faith to influence comics without preaching a message or creating a 20 page run down to what we all already know.  I wanted to present people of faith in a more realistic light.  I wanted to give believers and non - believers alike something that they can connect over and just maybe allow them the chance to spark some real conversation about their own journeys.  I mostly just want people to be inspired to make the world a better place for someone else the best they can.  

That is why this book is not a "Christian Comic".  It is, however, a comic written from a  Christian's world view.  It challenges people of faith just as much as it does those without it.  Hopefully, it blurs the lines that society draws to divide us and helps us all see that we have a bit more in common than we realize.  

Risks & Challenges

It's pretty tough taking the next step no matter what that step is.  For me, it's breaking the barrier of low print runs and subsequently limited sales.  Without some financial freedom to take a calculated risk, I won't be able to do that.  Additionally, rerunning the entire line to distribute to retailers with a more uniform look and feel could leave me with bundles of books in my garage if I don't manage to distribute to local shops.  

 

3 Ways to Help if $$ is Tight:

I know that a financial contribution may not be possible but you may still want to help with the cause.  Here are some ways that you can actively help get this project to the next level.

1. Join the Mailing List.  Go by lukestonestudios.com and join the mailing list for updates. 

2. Share the campaign with your friends and family through conversation, email, or social media.  Post it in Facebook groups and even let some of your favorite comics outlets know about the book!

3. Go to your local comic shop and ask if they would be willing to stock a couple copies of each issue for you.  We will do consignment but we are working right now to offer a 40% or greater discount to the retailers who purchase direct!

 

 

Some revisions to issue 1.

 

1 of 1 Line Art from ISSUE 4:

 

 

Adrian Fernandez Cover Art:

story:
Hi,‭ ‬it's Dave.‭ ‬I'm a freelance writer specializing in geek matters: I've written for Anime News Network, Otaku USA, Japan's own animeanime (in English), Colony Drop, and, one time, the dearly departed Joystiq.

I'm also the author of Kawaiikochan‭!! ‬Gaming no Korner,‭ ‬an unusual‭ ‬4-panel webcomic about two girls (Masaka is on the left, Majide is on the right) playing videogames,‭ ‬drinking bubble tea,‭ ‬and having a good time...‭ ‬while at the mercy of a capricious translation.

In mid-summer,‭ ‬I am going to be vacationing in Tokyo with friends.‭ ‬Given the nature of Kawaiikochans, a trip to Japan is obviously a huge opportunity for the comic, one I'm unlikely to have again for a long time.

That being such, I decided I'd take this chance for everything it's worth and turn my vacation into the biggest Kawaiikochan project ever: a travelogue in Japan with the gamesoft-loving kawaiis. I only get one shot at this, and to do it right, I'm going to need your help.


Shin Nihon Keikaku (The New Plan In Japan) is a book-length (100+ pages) travelogue in comic form. The Kawaiikochans are going to have a big adventure traveling around (mostly) Tokyo, focusing on gaming and arcades, with anime/manga and other geek fascinations sprinkled throughout.

(I'm not planning for print, however; at 100+ color pages, the print-on-demand solutions I've used in the past would be prohibitively expensive for a small comic like this one.)

They'll run you through Akiba inside and out. They'll go out of the way to hunt for treasure. They'll fill you in on games from Japan that few outside of the country know about or have even seen, in info-dense "all about" segments. They'll have fun in the usual silly Kawaiikochan comics that fans know and love.

The following sample mockup, made with photos from a 2012 Japan trip, should give you an idea of what to expect in the finished product. I also did a rough, early version of this treatment at Barcade in New York City.

The goal of the project is to find interesting and unusual stuff-- like an arcade inside of an airport where all the games are about flying commercial airliners-- and present it in a fun way, through the kawaiis.

See also the newly finished preview (1) (2), in which the Kawaiikochans see the gaming sights in my native New York City!



We'll be staying in Tokyo, a stone's throw from Akihabara, the geek district of the world, where maids hand out flyers on every street corner.

Akiba is by no means the only area of Tokyo I wish to explore‭: there's a lot there, but it's pretty small, geographically speaking! ‬However, it is certainly going to be home base for the vacation (our favorite videogame bar is there),‭ ‬and you can expect a full rundown of the area.‭ The plan is to start from Akiba, and work our way out.

We'll also be hopping on the Shinkansen all the way to Kyoto, with a detour in Osaka to see some wrestling! (Masaka wasn't kidding about that in the video. NJPW Dominion 2015. I bought the ticket. Get hype.)

As for what the kawaiis will be doing, the focus will of course be on their beloved gamesoft. If you're going to Japan and you love videogames, game centers (arcades) are an obvious choice. Unlike in the West, the Japanese arcade is still an active institution, and there are tons of games there that will never leave the arcade; in many cases they won't even leave the nation of Japan.

In addition to the traditional shooters and fighting games that gamers around the world know well,‭ ‬the Japanese arcade has been moving more and more to experiences that are impossible to replicate at home.

You can expect an arcade game version of beer pong, collectible card games that bring your cards to life on the battlefield, music games with increasingly bonkers controls, an online deathmatch light-gun shooter that requires you to make the poses from Equilibrium, and yes, that game where you flip a table. And that's just scratching the surface! I didn't even tell you about the 18-player horse race betting simulator!

There is so much fascinating stuff in Japanese arcades, and usually no way for people outside of Japan to play it but to get on a plane! One of the main goals of this project is to provide much-needed English-language coverage of this neglected corner of the gaming world.

Attention will also be given to the locations themselves, from the several world-class arcades within walking distance in Akiba, to the amusement park where the rides are also games, to the holes-in-the-wall where salarymen plug away at online mahjong under ceilings so low they can't stand up.


Though Majide's personal quest for more home gamesoft is so comprehensive it spans the whole universe, she can also show you where to go in the Akiba and Tokyo areas. The thrill of the hunt takes her from game shops so comprehensive they double as museums... to some places you might not think of looking.


Anime culture is in the blood of Kawaiikochans as much as it is in the blood of Akiba. The neighborhood is absolutely littered with anime and hobby shops! We're going to check out the spots and show you where to go for what. Here's another mockup page made from my 2012 visit to the life-size Gundam in Odaiba.


(Though this doesn't strictly fall into the "anime" category, I have already solemnly sworn to "location hunt" some spots from tokusatsu (live-action Japanese superhero) shows.)

Obviously not every single detail of the vacation is going to be about games, or anime, or even nerdy stuff. It would be sort of weird if it was, don't you think?

The place we’re staying, the places we visit, the trains and the vending machines and all that: they’ll get kawaiied up just as much as if they were videogames! The game stuff will be framed with these kinds of details.

It’s okay that the Kawaiikochans have been established canonically as already existing in Japan. They are still full of wonder, and everything is amazing to them.


I'm not actually going to be putting the comics together in Japan‭; ‬my time there is precious and I'm going to be trying to get as much done for this project as I possibly can in those nine days.‭ ‬Furthermore,‭ ‬this project is going to take a lot longer than nine days to put together.

Therefore, while I'm in Japan, armed with camera and notebook, I'm going to be a fairly obnoxious tourist. I'll be constantly jotting down notes and photographing until I'm asked to put the camera down (which does happen in Japan).

Once I'm home, the hard work of putting together the project begins, alongside my usual, promised work on the comics as usual (three four-panels a week, minimum).  At this time, Early Access donors will get to read the pages as they're worked on in a regular newsletter.

I am aiming to be done at the end of the year, and I am shooting to have 100 pages as an absolute, baseline minimum.

Exactly when I am done depends on how much material is in the completed project. Exactly how much material will be in the completed project depends on how much I'm able to see in Japan, which in turn depends on the funding of this project. Arcades in particular are expensive; a typical price per play is around $1 and games can get up to $5.

Unlike the past Kawaiikochan magazine projects, this project has a budget beyond my own free time, which is why I'm asking for help.

I am budgeting‭ ‬$3000‭ ‬for this trip.‭ ‬The bulk and the skull of that budget are going to travel costs: flight, room and board, and the rail pass for getting around the country. After all that, there's a little to eat on and a reasonable amount of spending money, much of which is going to all that arcade research. What? It's valuable work!

Fans of Kawaiikochan have already supported this comic, and turned it into my biggest personal project, in ways I would have never imagined when I started. First Lab Zero offered to put the girls into Skullgirls, and the fans funded it(find them in the casino stage!). Fans' regular support via Patreon keeps the comic going at a steady pace. I cannot properly express how thankful I am.

It is directly because that support has been demonstrated that I can even consider a project this large. Thank you, and I sincerely hope that you find this project as exciting and important and worthwhile as I do.

Patreon support from this month, next month (and a month before that) will go into the project. Proceeds from sales of Kawaiikochan merchandise (I get $6 a shirt, $1 for the first book and $4 for the second) will also be put towards the project. Of course, the best way to support is to donate directly!


This depends entirely on your donation to the project! Early Access donors and above will go on a newsletter where I'll be sharing the pages as I create them along with commentary: Patreon supporters are familiar with (and fond of, dare I say) the weekly newsletter. Your donation doesn't just help the project actually happen; it gets you in on a conversation that will help to shape it. Even before the project starts, I'd like to use this space to discuss things in greater depth with the donors. 

When the project is completely finished and I am completely satisfied with it, I'll be assembling all the pages into a big PDF that will go out to every Early Access member. Right now, print is not in the plans, as SNK is going to be quite big.

As for the public, Project SNK will be posted to the Kawaiikochan Tumblr much later, as a weekly trickle over a long period of time. If you want it soon, please support the project!


First and foremost, all donors at all levels will be thanked in the acknowledgements section of the book.

With Early Access ($30, $25 for Early Birds) you get in on the project from the start and help to shape it! Once I get back from Japan, the process of creating Project SNK actually begins. As I put it together, page by page, you're going to see those pages in an e-mail newsletter/mailing list. When the project is finally finished, Early Access backers will get a complete PDF of Project SNK.

Next, the Early Access Plus Personal Thank-You And Try This Gamesoft Card Level ($50) gets you a personalized thank-you card from the kawaii of your choice. At this level, tell me your name or preferred handle (nothing dirty), your favorite kawaii (two is fine too) and the videogame genre in which you'd like a recommendation.

Let’s say your name is Such’N’Such Tanaka. You tell me: “Neco Masaka, Golf”

I say, “Is Neo Turf Masters alright?” You say yes, obviously; if you asked me for golf you must have wanted me to say Neo Turf Masters in the first place.

I make you a one-panel card of Neco Masaka thanking you, Such’N’Such Tanaka, for your service to the cause and enthusiastically recommending Neo Turf Masters. See a sample. There will be a top number of 20 of these.

The highest reward is Pick a Gamesoft, Pick Any Gamesoft. ($100) In addition to the previous rewards, choose an arcade game in Tokyo that you’d like to see get the Kawaiikochan treatment. Your game will get a minimum of two pages in the book.

If you’ve ever seen “Tama-ge” (You Should Go To This Game Center Sometime) on the Japanese TV show Game Center CX, the format for these pages will be directly like that. The characters read a “letter” written by you (brief and concise to fit on the page, be polite, keep it PG) like Arino does at the beginning of the segments, and then do a rundown on whatever game is chosen. To give you an idea, here's another mockup for a "Johnny Maximum," whoever he is.

The game has to be reasonably available within Tokyo: for most modern games this really shouldn’t be a big deal. There is also the caveat that if it’s a rare game I can only play in one place, and if that place isn’t cool with photos, I won’t be able to take any pictures. I don’t want that to happen to you!

Other than that, there isn’t really any restriction on this. Children’s games, pachinko, I don’t care. If you want me to play Aikatsu, I’ll do it. Believe it. There are five of these spots.


Every Patreon supporter whose total donation amount (over the duration of the Fan/Fun club's existence) is over $30 by the end of May gets Early Access. Some of you, who've been Grand Sponsor level donors from the start, will get there regardless. It's also completely okay by me to change your pledge for that one month and then go back to normal! So long as you cross the line by the end of May, I'll be sending you the same Early Access newsletter as I'll be sending Patreon donors.

I don't want Patreon donors to feel left in the cold on this new project; this is my way of saying thank you for being all in for the last six months. You are all literally the reason I decided to reach out and take on a project of this scale.

Furthermore, any Patreon donor who also contributes to the project via the Indiegogo achieves the status of MEGA SPONSOR for going above and beyond. They will be credited as such, with pomp and fanfare, in the book's acknowledgement section.

There aren't a lot of risks and challenges involved with this project. However, I must offer the all-purpose caveat that sometimes, places in Japan will not be okay with photography. I want to respect the wishes of the establishments, and if I'm asked to stop taking photos I will.

This is a flex fund campaign, meaning I get the funding whether or not the goal is met. This does not mean that I run off with your money if it isn't! It means the project continues, in a diminished capacity. With your help, I'm confident we can bring this project to its full shining glory.

Finally! Whether or not you decide to support this project, I'd like to thank you for managing to read this far. I know it was long. You're very patient. If you can't support the project yourself, you can still help by sharing this campaign everywhere you can; it's more help than you know. Again, on the behalf of myself and the kawaiis, thanks so much.
story_txt:
Hi,‭ ‬it's Dave.‭ ‬I'm a freelance writer specializing in geek matters: I've written for Anime News Network, Otaku USA, Japan's own animeanime (in English), Colony Drop, and, one time, the dearly departed Joystiq.I'm also the author of Kawaiikochan‭!! ‬Gaming no Korner,‭ ‬an unusual‭ ‬4-panel webcomic about two girls (Masaka is on the left, Majide is on the right) playing videogames,‭ ‬drinking bubble tea,‭ ‬and having a good time...‭ ‬while at the mercy of a capricious translation.In mid-summer,‭ ‬I am going to be vacationing in Tokyo with friends.‭ ‬Given the nature of Kawaiikochans, a trip to Japan is obviously a huge opportunity for the comic, one I'm unlikely to have again for a long time. That being such, I decided I'd take this chance for everything it's worth and turn my vacation into the biggest Kawaiikochan project ever: a travelogue in Japan with the gamesoft-loving kawaiis. I only get one shot at this, and to do it right, I'm going to need your help.   
 
Shin Nihon Keikaku (The New Plan In Japan) is a book-length (100+ pages) travelogue in comic form. The Kawaiikochans are going to have a big adventure traveling around (mostly) Tokyo, focusing on gaming and arcades, with anime/manga and other geek fascinations sprinkled throughout.(I'm not planning for print, however; at 100+ color pages, the print-on-demand solutions I've used in the past would be prohibitively expensive for a small comic like this one.)They'll run you through Akiba inside and out. They'll go out of the way to hunt for treasure. They'll fill you in on games from Japan that few outside of the country know about or have even seen, in info-dense "all about" segments. They'll have fun in the usual silly Kawaiikochan comics that fans know and love.The following sample mockup, made with photos from a 2012 Japan trip, 
should give you an idea of what to expect in the finished product. I 
also did a rough, early version of this treatment at Barcade in New York City.

The goal of the project is to find interesting and unusual stuff-- like an arcade inside of an airport where all the games are about flying commercial airliners-- and present it in a fun way, through the kawaiis.See also the newly finished preview (1) (2), in which the Kawaiikochans see the gaming sights in my native New York City!We'll be staying in Tokyo, a stone's throw from Akihabara, the geek district of the world, where maids hand out flyers on every street corner.Akiba is by no means the only area of Tokyo I wish to explore‭: there's a lot there, but it's pretty small, geographically speaking! ‬However, it is certainly going to be home base for the vacation (our favorite videogame bar is there),‭ ‬and you can expect a full rundown of the area.‭ The plan is to start from Akiba, and work our way out.We'll also be hopping on the Shinkansen all the way to Kyoto, with a detour in Osaka to see some wrestling! (Masaka wasn't kidding about that in the video. NJPW Dominion 2015. I bought the ticket. Get hype.)As for what the kawaiis will be doing, the focus will of course be on their beloved gamesoft. If you're going to Japan and you love videogames, game centers (arcades) are an obvious choice. Unlike in the West, the Japanese arcade is still an active institution, and there are tons of games there that will never leave the arcade; in many cases they won't even leave the nation of Japan.In addition to the traditional shooters and fighting games that gamers around the world know well,‭ ‬the Japanese arcade has been moving more and more to experiences that are impossible to replicate at home. You can expect an arcade game version of beer pong, collectible card games that bring your cards to life on the battlefield, music games with increasingly bonkers controls, an online deathmatch light-gun shooter that requires you to make the poses from Equilibrium, and yes, that game where you flip a table. And that's just scratching the surface! I didn't even tell you about the 18-player horse race betting simulator!There is so much fascinating stuff in Japanese arcades, and usually no way for people outside of Japan to play it but to get on a plane! One of the main goals of this project is to provide much-needed English-language coverage of this neglected corner of the gaming world. Attention will also be given to the locations themselves, from the several world-class arcades within walking distance in Akiba, to the amusement park where the rides are also games, to the holes-in-the-wall where salarymen plug away at online mahjong under ceilings so low they can't stand up.
Though Majide's personal quest for more home gamesoft is so comprehensive it spans the whole universe, she can also show you where to go in the Akiba and Tokyo areas. The thrill of the hunt takes her from game shops so comprehensive they double as museums... to some places you might not think of looking.
Anime culture is in the blood of Kawaiikochans as much as it is in the blood of Akiba. The neighborhood is absolutely littered with anime and hobby shops! We're going to check out the spots and show you where to go for what. Here's another mockup page made from my 2012 visit to the life-size Gundam in Odaiba.
(Though this doesn't strictly fall into the "anime" category, I have already solemnly sworn to "location hunt" some spots from tokusatsu (live-action Japanese superhero) shows.)Obviously not every single detail of the vacation is going to be about games, or anime, or even nerdy stuff. It would be sort of weird if it was, don't you think?The place we’re staying, the places we visit, the trains and the vending machines and all that: they’ll get kawaiied up just as much as if they were videogames! The game stuff will be framed with these kinds of details.It’s okay that the Kawaiikochans have been established canonically as already existing in Japan. They are still full of wonder, and everything is amazing to them.
I'm not actually going to be putting the comics together in Japan‭; ‬my time there is precious and I'm going to be trying to get as much done for this project as I possibly can in those nine days.‭ ‬Furthermore,‭ ‬this project is going to take a lot longer than nine days to put together.Therefore, while I'm in Japan, armed with camera and notebook, I'm going to be a fairly obnoxious tourist. I'll be constantly jotting down notes and photographing until I'm asked to put the camera down (which does happen in Japan).Once I'm home, the hard work of putting together the project begins, alongside my usual, promised work on the comics as usual (three four-panels a week, minimum).  At this time, Early Access donors will get to read the pages as they're worked on in a regular newsletter.I am aiming to be done at the end of the year, and I am shooting to have 100 pages as an absolute, baseline minimum.Exactly when I am done depends on how much material is in the completed project. Exactly how much material will be in the completed project depends on how much I'm able to see in Japan, which in turn depends on the funding of this project. Arcades in particular are expensive; a typical price per play is around $1 and games can get up to $5.
Unlike the past Kawaiikochan magazine projects, this project has a budget beyond my own free time, which is why I'm asking for help.
I am budgeting‭ ‬$3000‭ ‬for this trip.‭ ‬The bulk and the skull of that budget are going to travel costs: flight, room and board, and the rail pass for getting around the country. After all that, there's a little to eat on and a reasonable amount of spending money, much of which is going to all that arcade research. What? It's valuable work!
Fans of Kawaiikochan have already supported this comic, and turned it into my biggest personal project, in ways I would have never imagined when I started. First Lab Zero offered to put the girls into Skullgirls, and the fans funded it(find them in the casino stage!). Fans' regular support via Patreon keeps the comic going at a steady pace. I cannot properly express how thankful I am.
It is directly because that support has been demonstrated that I can 
even consider a project this large. Thank you, and I sincerely hope that
 you find this project as exciting and important and worthwhile as I do.
Patreon support from this month, next month (and a month before that) 
will go into the project. Proceeds from sales of Kawaiikochan 
merchandise (I get $6 a shirt, $1 for the first book and $4 for the second) 
will also be put towards the project. Of course, the best way to support
 is to donate directly!

story:
ComicMix presents the drug fueled cyberpunk fever dream Hallucination that is the graphic novel UKIYO


What is UKIYO?

Ghost In The Shell + Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas + Only lovers Left Alive = UKIYO

UKIYO. The word conjures images of the lives of Japanese courtesans and the nobility, a life of excess and luxury. Or it can mean "sorrowful world." A "transitory world." An implication of a separate, illusory reality. A staging place for the afterlife. Author and illustrator  Cary Polkovitz's UKIYO centers on an existence based on varying perceptions. Hallucinatory visuals tell a tale inspired by the rapidly advancing technologies of today's social media and global economic interconnectivity. UKIYO is a study in non-linear storytelling, drugs, online personas, and obsession.

How good is UKIYO?

“Intriguing and heartfelt, with great feeling and atmosphere.”

- Jock, Wytches, Batman, Hellblazer, Judge Dredd, Daredevil, The Losers, Comic Book Tattoo

"a necessary diet for those prone to thinking past the third dimension, and asking questions about life on the other side of wormholes."

- PREVIEWSWorld

“Very impressive. A serious and sophisticated piece of work."

-Dave Elliott, A1, Sharky, Heavy Metal, Weirding Willows, Monster Massacre

This is your chance to read the 300 page graphic novel magnum opus UKIYO  that PREVIEWSWorld called, "a necessary diet for those prone to thinking past the third dimension, and asking questions about life on the other side of wormholes."

$8 -Early Bird sale: UKIYO
UKIYO, the 300 page cyberpunk magnum opus graphic novel, PDF Edition.
This is the only time you will be able to get it at this price. Limited amount so take advantage of this special offer.

The artist of UKIYO

 Creator Cary Polkovitz cut his teeth as writer and penciler for NeoTek Iconography’s NAU Headhunter during his college years at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. He then went on to illustrate “Miss Adventure” and “Kodiak” for Men’s Adventure and Penthouse Comix through the mid 90s. Taking a break to teach art and become a well-known painter in South Florida’s “low-brow” art scene, and to have two volumes of his short stories published, Cary has since come back to his roots in the comic book industry.

His newest work is featured in ComicMix’s charity book for Norm Breyfogle, The Whisper Campaign, and is currently working on the companion piece to UKIYO, genius loci. Cary also publishes a slice-of-life webcomic called Meaning But Without the Words.


UKIYO is also available from your local comic retailer. Previews Ukiyo HC (OCT151302)

story:
Our Story

My name is Aleksi Siirtola. I am a 24-year-old aspiring cartoonist and graphic novel aficionado, attempting to break into the comic business. In development since 2007, my series "The Fugitive Below the Surface" is a dark, mature fantasy graphic novel series centered around the exploits of its protagonist Everett Montano and his quest for vengeance.

Unfortunately, the series - the first part now finished and the second one in production - was not picked up by any publisher, and thus its existence relies on the sales of self-published copies and much-appreciated donations.

That is where You come in.

The Impact

Drawing comics is cheap and very fun - the estimated costs of creating Conviction (the first part of the Fugitive series) were only about 250$. Sadly, self-publishing comics and getting computers strong enough to run software to color your art is not cheap. That is why I'm asking for Your help: any donation will help, and will be rewarded (refer to the perk list on the right for more info on that :)

How will donations aid the comic? They will make the Fugitive Below the Surface possible, and speed up its production - the less worries and trouble with money, the more time to draw! Finding a publisher is also rather costly, and is far easier to do with the aid of donations.


What We Need & What You Get

100% of donations will go to further the cause of the Fugitive Below the Surface: printing copies and sending them to publishers, getting better hardware, buying equipment (paper, pens, ink etc.) and so on.

If you're worried that I won't be reaching my full goal, don't worry. Every last cent helps and makes the drawing process easier, not to mention attempts to acquire a publisher.

What will you get for your donation? Intangibly, you get to help a struggling artist along, and know that you helped to realize The Fugitive Below the Surface: The Insurrection. Tangibly, donators are credited, given exclusive digital artbooks (one that isn't for sale, only available to donators) and unique memorabilia with sufficiently high donations.


Other Ways You Can Help

Impressed with the comic but can't afford to donate? Don't worry - spread the word! No matter how you choose to share The Fugitive Below the Surface - be it facebook, twitter, myspace, podcasts, personal websites or just good ol' word of mouth - it is more than welcome. Want to post a review of the comic? Please do. Want to interview the creator? It can be arranged. However you're willing to spread the word, we welcome it :)


The Fugitive Below the Surface: Conviction

Conviction is the first part of the Fugitive series. Taking place in a fantasy setting in the late industrial age and following the exploits of Everett Montano, a young man who becomes entangled in revenge after his best friend is brutally murdered in front of his eyes, Conviction is at the same time sad, touching, funny and gripping. 

Everett's vengeance proves more difficult than expected, however, when he is unable to find the killer. To do so, he enlists the help of a clandestine criminal service, but is forced to work as an assassin in order to pay for the rather expensive services. Will Everett find his friend's killer, and will he be able to not lose himself as his passion for revenge consumes him?


The Fugitive Below the Surface: Insurrection

The direct sequel to Conviction, Insurrection deals with the destructive civil war of Everett's adoptive country, the Depthlands. A war epic spread throughout two generations, Insurrection views war through the eyes of Gabionades Sinda, a strategic genius and a maverick among the fiercely traditional Tsagan culture, Ronaldo NAD, a fierce gangster who was forced to become a criminal due to omnipresent racism and Everett, the young refugee protagonist of Conviction. A dark, powerful tale of political intrigue, betrayal, war, assassination and love, the insurrection will leave no one untouched. Will Everett be able to assassinate the leader of the opposing army, and stop the destructive civil war that ravages the Depthlands and its denizens?


Full List of Expenses

For those who are interested, this is a full listing of the things I will be spending any possible donations on:

* Paper, pencils, pens, inks and other assorted drawing tools (estimated: 200-300$)

* A new printed edition of the Fugitive Below the Surface: Conviction (estimated: 2000-3000$. You need to make a sufficiently large edition in order to make the copies cheap enough for purchasers.)

* A new computer for colorization, to speed up progress on the Insurrection (estimated: 4000$)

* Promotion costs (i.e. postage costs, free copies etc) for the series to obtain a publisher (estimated 100$+)

* Any other funds that exceed the above will be saved for any instance that requires them (such as my drawing tablet, which is getting on in years, might break down and need replacement), so that Insurrection can have my full attention. Full attention = comic done faster -> happy fans and happy creator yay !

100% of donations will go to further the cause of the Fugitive Below the Surface: printing copies and sending them to publishers, getting better hardware, buying equipment (paper, pens, ink etc.) and so on.
If you're worried that I won't be reaching my full goal, don't worry. Every last cent helps and makes the drawing process easier, not to mention attempts to acquire a publisher.
What will you get for your donation? Intangibly, you get to help a struggling artist along, and know that you helped to realize The Fugitive Below the Surface: The Insurrection. Tangibly, donators are credited, given exclusive digital artbooks (one that isn't for sale, only available to donators) and unique memorabilia with sufficiently high donations.


Other Ways You Can Help
Impressed with the comic but can't afford to donate? Don't worry - spread the word! No matter how you choose to share The Fugitive Below the Surface - be it facebook, twitter, myspace, podcasts, personal websites or just good ol' word of mouth - it is more than welcome. Want to post a review of the comic? Please do. Want to interview the creator? It can be arranged. However you're willing to spread the word, we welcome it :)

The Fugitive Below the Surface: Conviction
Conviction is the first part of the Fugitive series. Taking place in a fantasy setting in the late industrial age and following the exploits of Everett Montano, a young man who becomes entangled in revenge after his best friend is brutally murdered in front of his eyes, Conviction is at the same time sad, touching, funny and gripping. 
Everett's vengeance proves more difficult than expected, however, when he is unable to find the killer. To do so, he enlists the help of a clandestine criminal service, but is forced to work as an assassin in order to pay for the rather expensive services. Will Everett find his friend's killer, and will he be able to not lose himself as his passion for revenge consumes him? 

The Fugitive Below the Surface: Insurrection
The direct sequel to Conviction, Insurrection deals with the destructive civil war of Everett's adoptive country, the Depthlands. A war epic spread throughout two generations, Insurrection views war through the eyes of Gabionades Sinda, a strategic genius and a maverick among the fiercely traditional Tsagan culture, Ronaldo NAD, a fierce gangster who was forced to become a criminal due to omnipresent racism and Everett, the young refugee protagonist of Conviction. A dark, powerful tale of political intrigue, betrayal, war, assassination and love, the insurrection will leave no one untouched. Will Everett be able to assassinate the leader of the opposing army, and stop the destructive civil war that ravages the Depthlands and its denizens?

Full List of Expenses
For those who are interested, this is a full listing of the things I will be spending any possible donations on:
* Paper, pencils, pens, inks and other assorted drawing tools (estimated: 200-300$)
* A new printed edition of the Fugitive Below the Surface: Conviction (estimated: 2000-3000$. You need to make a sufficiently large edition in order to make the copies cheap enough for purchasers.)
* A new computer for colorization, to speed up progress on the Insurrection (estimated: 4000$)
* Promotion costs (i.e. postage costs, free copies etc) for the series to obtain a publisher (estimated 100$+)
* Any other funds that exceed the above will be saved for any instance that requires them (such as my drawing tablet, which is getting on in years, might break down and need replacement), so that Insurrection can have my full attention. Full attention = comic done faster -> happy fans and happy creator yay !

story:
The Samurai Chef is a comic that follows the escalating culinary battle between contestants and the toughest chef on TV! It's shown on a fantasy TV network called mayamada and this project is to create a 50 page perfect bound edition.

The funds raised will be used to pay artist fees and manufacture + distribute an initial print run of the book this autumn/fall.


What's The Samurai Chef? 

It starts out as a simple cooking competition. However, it quickly becomes clear that contestants are not fully prepared for the strict measures of the Samurai Chef...

As their best creations are continuously put to the sword, the contestants decide to team up to create tougher dishes better able stand up to the judging process.

Meanwhile, far from the mayamada studio, events are being viewed by some of the world's most decorated chefs who become intrigued with it all.

A live show is interrupted as the current crop of contestants are sent away by this new breed of challengers eager to test their "superior" skills against the Samurai Chef.

And these are no ordinary challengers. They have their own teams, have studied the show and are confident they have what it takes to overcome the strict judging process.

The reason for their confidence? The ability to bring their speciality dishes to life. Literally.

With each creation now able to fight back, the chef now has his work cut out for him!

The Samurai Chef Pilot Sample

We willbe working with the artist Pinali - Creator of sci-fi webcomic Alter, and responsible for lots of the artwork already on the mayamada network website. 

.

What do I get for supporting you? 

Apart from that feel good factor for helping a small start-up make their dream come true you get the following (with more on the side of this page):

Pledge $5 – your name will be in amazing  ASCII art Credits much like the image below and much better than boring only column credits.

 

Pledge $10 – You will get your name in the credits AND a cool set of Samurai Chef pin badges to remind you of your support.

You will also get an electronic copy of the 50 page book, DRM Free.

For $25 You get a signed copy of the Samurai Chef book + badges + credits

 

Jumping ahead at $75 we even give you the opportunity to have your very own pet in the show as an extra (contestant) – just send us a picture. Limited number of these though. 

 

 

And there are many more great rewards on the side of this page.

 

What you can do to help:

Even if you cannot support us with a donation, you still help us reach our goal. Sharing this project via Facebook, Twitter and word of mouth. The more people that know about it the better chance we stand to reach our goal so we depend on you :) .

 

What if you are overfunded?

If we raise more funds than we the original target then we will unlock new shows from the mayamada network as bonus comics. Beyond that, we have a few surprises and free upgrades for all donators.

story:
Update (November 3rd, 2011)

We have some new images of character designs for you all to see!


Update (October 31st, 2011)

And so it begins.

I have just recently finished the scripting of the short prologue for the first of a series of web comics set in the world of Evadire that I have spent so long crafting from the ground up.

This first story follows the life of Faron Vaelen, the young daughter of a blacksmith and former war veteran from a poor fishing village named Port Orastine as she learns from a mysterious old friend of his father's what the goddess of fate has in store for her future.

Faron will learn the many arts of magic and become stronger as she grows older. She will raise up above the call of duty and fight alongside her allies as a new war begins, and a much more sinister threat emerges from its ashes.

I hope this has intrigued you all a little more than this project has been, and I hope that you will join us regularly as this project gets underway!

Our Story

Hey there everyone,


My name is Christopher Porter. I am a 20 year old writer from Newfoundland, Canada looking to start my own online comic book company


Right now I'm just focusing on raising the funds that I require in order to get my business up and running legitimately by getting it incorporated, getting my website designed professionally to suit my needs and to get that small portion of extra cash to fund my projects by paying for the artwork that I require. For this I am asking for $1,820 US dollars.


So far, the work that myself and my artist have been able to achieve has been funded solely by me personally from working over-nights at a local Subway, paying what I can to him when I can afford it after bills. After working so long and hard, it is good to see that my dream of owning my very own online media company has the potential to be waiting right around the corner.


The Impact

It is my firm belief that if I am unable to start my online media business, that the world would be missing out on the great story-lines, and world design that I put so much time and effort to create for our projects. I love writing and always have. I don't want to let what talent I have go to waste.

However, if I don't meet the funding this time around I plan to keep trying until I do reach my goal of business incorporation. I refuse to abandon my dream, and I will not let the above scenario take place, even if I have to scrounge every penny I make myself to get it started.


What We Have Been Working On So Far

There are a handful of projects that we are working on. Some are in the planning stages, some are in the scripting stages, and there is one that is currently in the fleshing stage. These projects range from medium sized workloads to large sized workloads.

Evadire (Huge Project) [Fantasy World + Online Graphic Novel Series]

This project has been my baby for going on three years now. I have spent countless hours working on the back-history of an entire fantasy universe and building every detail piece by piece from the ground up.

My goal is to create a pseudo-realistic fantasy world with a rich history and mythology that would be capable of snatching up the reader's attention. I'm the kind of writer that feels that the history of a fantasy world should be the driving point for your stories, not the other way around. Sometimes it's worth the extra hard work in creating your world as detailed as possible, even if some of the details are never included in an actual story-line. You will always have those types of fans who love to read page after page of rich history before they would ever think about picking up one of your stories.

Blood Moon (Medium Project) [Online Graphic Novel Series]

This project is currently in the scripting stages. It will be an online graphic novel set in the 1950's and will follow the story of Felix Santana - a former cop turned vampire who is searching for answers as to why his wife and young daughter were killed during an attack by vampires and he was turned instead of sharing their fate. Along his journey he becomes tangled in a war between two separate factions of vampire, the Children of Magdalene, and the Crown of the Beast.

Ubiquity Complex (Huge Project) [Sci-Fi World + Online Graphic Novel Series]

This project is currently only in the planning stages. Much like the Evadire project, it will require a great deal of time as it requires the creation of an entire sci-fi universe.

The basic storyline behind the Ubiquity Complex project is based on the creation of a massive underground bunker that houses the world's most elite soldiers, frozen in stasis pods and connected up with a series of computers and the Ubiquity Complex, a series of machines located around the galaxies that can instantly create a replica of the soldiers within the stasis pods in far off war-zones. The recreated human soldier is able to control from the safety of their pod within the bunker.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is the general breakdown of what I need and where it's going in order of importance. If I don't reach the funding, I will be using what I do raise to go towards things listed at the top of the list first, and work my way down.


$20 - NUANS name search (To ensure that the business name is in-fact available. If it is not, this will just be a minor set-back that can be corrected easily enough.)

$200 - Incorporation fees (I want to make sure this business venture is as legit as possible, so this requires incorporation.)

$300-600 - Website design (In order to have an attractive business on the internet you have to have an attractive website that lures in the people who will appreciate it the most.)

$1000 - Paying artists (As my first project once the business is up and running properly, I have planned out an online graphic novel that will require artists matched with my scripts.)


These particular fees that will require payment equal out to the total $1820 that I am seeking.


Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you are able to donate to the cause, choose not to, or simply are unable to -- please remember that you can use the Indiegogo share tools to share to all your friends. The extra help is always welcome and always, ALWAYS appreciated.

story:
Hello, my name is Tyler. I'm 23. I wrote a zombie story unlike any other.  The story will be about 120 pages.
 
 
 
The illustrations are by Brian. here's his web site.  www.briansteward.com
 
Street Racing Zombie Killers is a story that takes places five years after the zombie outbreak.  The bombs have dropped leaving very few supplies.  There are sectors where people live all over the world and each sector has a race team.  They race each other for supplies as a way to not only keep some type of humanity but for survival.
 
money raised on this campaign will go towards the ilustrations, getting prints made, and copy righting.

story:
Luis Figueiredo Cover

What We Need & What You Get

Our target is $1,500 for this campaign. What does that cover? First and foremost that gets this book printed and in your hands. 

Beyond the cost of printing and shipping the book, funds will go right into creating issue number two and developing new Concept Moon projects!

In issue #1 you will get a 24-page story starting with the arrival of a Prince from the stars, as well as a sneak, peek of our next project "Assata: The Fallen Blade". 

Issue #1 is the start of an ongoing series of comics dedicated to telling an amazing story and building our Concept Moon Universe!

The Impact

This is the first project for us here at Concept Moon, we took the big initial steps of finding and hiring the phenomenal artists that made this comic book. Making this campaign a success will mean a future for Concept Moon and continued stories of all genres for comic book fans.

Risks & Challenges

NONE! This book is already completed in digital form, and available for purchase on via our website (www.ConceptMoon.com)! All the pages and the variant covers are finished, and our Stretch Goals are in-work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't back the book financially? Not a problem! 

You can now simply share the link with your family and friends. If you can confirm three purchases of either the digital book or the hardcopy you will receive a free copy of the book!

To verify the purchases simply have your friends/family send you screenshots of their completed contributions, then you simply forward them to our email (conceptmoonstudios@gmail.com) with the subject line "FREE BOOKS".  After we bump the names against our contributions list you will receive a confirmation email that name has been added to our free book listing.

How We Will Be Giving Back

For every purchase made over $5, we will put our own money where our mouth is and donate copies of our original Concept Moon Coloring Books to children's hospitals and Veteran Hospitals to help combat anxiety and ease mental health stressors! #CombatMentalHealth 

Stretch Goals

  $3000 XXXXXXXLOCKEDXXXXXXXXXXXXX

  $5000 XXXXXXXLOCKEDXXXXXXXXXXXXX

$10000 XXXXXXXLOCKEDXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Muh Sahrudin Variant Cover

story:
THE BALLAD OF DUSTY TORTILLAS #1

My name is Brendan Kemp, creator and co-writer of "TBODT". The team and I are extremely excited to bring you the first issue of an ongoing series  introducing you to a rich world inhabited by dynamic characters and period accurate set pieces. The project is being cowritten by my brother, Stephen Kemp, with interior art by P.Kay and colors by Michael Beacon. 

This will be the second round of funding for TBODT. Due to circumstances outside of our control, changes had to be made and the creative team was reorganized. We're excited about the new look and also about giving those that missed the original campaign a second chance to grab a first print!

On behalf of the team I'd like to thank you for considering this project. Its our sincerest hope that you will come to love these characters and share the enthusiasm for the story that we do. Now saddle up and enjoy the ride as we discover that for Dusty and his friends, the end of the wild west was just the beginning. 

11"X17" MISS LYNX PRINT INCLUDED IN THREE OF A KIND AND GUNSLINGER PERK

story:
Warbound, an immortal anti-hero on a quest for revenge. Or a delusional violent super vigilante? Villains fear him. Heroes don't trust him. Now, locked in a mental asylum for superpowers people, his only chance at freedom is a session with Dr. Kendra Jones. What truths will be revealed?

What are you backing?

  • This is a 32 page full color comic.
  • Superhero genre
  • Teen Readers

Marcel Dupree Creator/Story

Born in San Diego, California. He owns and operates Evoluzione Publishing. Either creator or co-creator of comics such as Le Fay, POM, SFC, Babylon Working, Seeing Red.

Guido Martinez Story/Script

Born and based in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Lover of superhero, action and fantasy comics. Creator of stuff that hopefully some day people around the world will enjoy. Appreciative of creativity, open-minded sense of humor and bright colors. Metal music and fighting games enthusiast. Creator of Knight and PIS.  Also, co-creator, co-writer and co-plotter of Three Thorns and SFC. Enjoy!

Gaurav Shrivastava - Artist

I'm a Comic book artist from a small town Morena, India. I have been reading comics and drawing stuff since I was a 4. My career began with holycow entertainment where i did numerous titles.  I am known for my dynamic muscular superhero art also for beautiful women drawing. I have won the best penciller award for my best selling title the last asuran. I am now working with Evoluzione Publishing and other indie publishers.

story:
TRUMP'S SPACE FORCE

Trump's Space Force is a high octane, kinetic thrill ride blending over-the-top science fiction adventure with political satire and humor. With the announcement of the real-life Space Force becoming a reality and the current state of the comics industry catering to a one-sided ideology, the team behind Trump's Space Force wants to deliver a quality book that tells a great story, captures the current zeitgeist, and entertains with dynamic art.

*Stretch Goals Unlocked*

Thanks to your support, these are the stretch goals that have not only been unlocked but are applicable to ALL tiers of support:

$35,000: Graham Nolan Back Cover

$39,000: Robert Harkin Postcard Assortment

$46,500: Space Trump Trading Card

$55,000: 48 Page Extension

Locked: $66,000: Square Bound, Cardstock Finish

SAMPLE ARTWORK:

Make Perks Great Again!

The $15,000 goal will cover our kind sponsors, general overhead, and pay the creative team for the work put into this book. The book is more than 1/3 of the way completed, meaning that backers should be seeing the finished product by fall of this year should we meet our goals.

  • $250: signed book, patch, hat, Roster printing, and one limited to 20 Dave Dorman canvas print!

The MAGAverse

Thanks to all our backers and friends who have been with our creative team since Clinton Cash (2016)! With Trump's Space Force, we are also using this as a vehicle for promoting independent talent by having characters from our network of friends appear in the story. You never know who will show up next!
story_txt:
TRUMP'S SPACE FORCE
Trump's Space Force is a high octane, kinetic thrill ride blending over-the-top science fiction adventure with political satire and humor. With the announcement of the real-life Space Force becoming a reality and the current state of the comics industry catering to a one-sided ideology, the team behind Trump's Space Force wants to deliver a quality book that tells a great story, captures the current zeitgeist, and entertains with dynamic art.
*Stretch Goals Unlocked*
Thanks to your support, these are the stretch goals that have not only been unlocked but are applicable to ALL tiers of support:
$35,000: Graham Nolan Back Cover

$39,000: Robert Harkin Postcard Assortment


$46,500: Space Trump Trading Card


$55,000: 48 Page Extension

story:
Voluntaryist Origins IV

The Voluntaryist Origins IV campaign continues the series in detailing how the protagonist, Jack Lloyd, and his new-found friend, Mack Lee, attempt to rescue Jack’s parents. What mysteries will Jack and Mack uncover in their fight to stop the total enslavement of humanity? Find out in Voluntaryist Origins IV by getting a copy for yourself here on Indiegogo!

Comic Book Backstory

Voluntaryist is the tale of a superhuman hero who finds himself pitted against the government as the government tries to enslave humanity once and for all.  He is a young man with extraordinary powers created through a chance encounter with cosmic radiation. His personal mission is to rescue his parents from government agents, but that objective is often frustrated with the likes of giant monsters, super-villains, and even the armed forces.

The comic takes a contemporary look at the question, "What does it mean to be truly free?"

You can learn more about the comic series universe over at www.volcomic.com

---INTERIOR PAGE FROM THE LAST ISSUE---

---INTERIOR PAGE FROM THE LAST ISSUE---

Creator History

Voluntaryist was created by liberty fanatic and producer Jack L., whose passion for liberty is only matched by his passion for memes and film production. He began the long process of creating the series while trudging through his graduate studies.

The Voluntaryist comic series was in a prototyping process for 6 years and is now showcasing the canon origins story. The script for this issue has been written and the characters have been established through several future-verse comic issues available at www.volcomic.com

The comic series has seen exponential growth with over 100% funding on recent campaigns and is poised to grow bigger than ever!

The Goal for Origins IV

20 new comic pages estimated for a 100% funded campaign.

We will produce as much of the comic as we can get funded for! The story is ongoing, so we will keep producing as much content as we can with this issue and then continue to move forward with future campaigns as we have done each year.

To get there, we need to raise $5,000 so this comic issue's potential is fully running.

The expenses are largely for the cost of hiring artists to produce the comic and the expenses associated with putting the comic into print format.

You can support us by making a secure contribution on the right-hand side by Credit Card/Debit Card.

You can redeem perks for your support such as:

The digital early release ($3)

Game Card Prototype ($40)

Vinyl Sticker ($65)

Patch ($75)

The Signed comic ($80)

Art Print ($100)

Full page advertisement ($200)

AND MUCH MORE!

Risks & Challenges

We are well-established in our development and are veteran Indiegogo users as this is our 10th COMIC CAMPAIGN on Indiegogo. So if you're looking to support a cool comic project that has a professional team with a proven track of success, look no further! We understand that there are a number of potential issues with shutdowns and shipments, but we are planning accordingly and want to assure you that we are using best practices to ensure we deliver by or before our estimated delivery dates.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you do not have pocket change to spare at the moment, you can help support the campaign by sharing the link to your social media, whether that's on Facebook, YouTube, Minds, MeWe, Steemit, Flote, or Reddit. We appreciate anything you can do to help us succeed!

story:
USAssassin Returns!

USAssassin Book II: Enter Zeroface is a 50 page graphic novel by writer Mark Poulton (Graveyard Shift, Hawkman) and artist Mike McMahon with colors by Oliver Lee Arce. 

New villains unite to take down government super agent, Joe Knight, in a story inspired by action films The Raid and Bruce Lee's Game of Death. When Joe awakens in the basement of building he must work his way up each level where new threats await him. A mysterious man from his past is at the head of this and it leads Joe to think back to his past as a young recruit of the Project USAssassin Program, where he was trained by Sensei Steel. 

The art for this book is 100% completed by Mike McMahon and currently being colored by Oliver Lee Arce. Once the campaign has ended and the funds are transferred to my account, I expect this to go to the printer. I am giving an estimated February 2021 fulfillment date but I hope to have this in everyone's hands a lot sooner. All books will come signed by writer/co-creator Mark Poulton. 

Cover by Mike McMahon and Anthony George

Book II Variant Cover by Kevin Sharpe (to be colored by Frank M Cuonzo)

Book II Wraparound Variant Cover by Ced Nocon (to be colored by Frank M Cuonzo)

The campaign also features a reprint of the 80 page Book I: Old Habits... graphic novel featuring an all new cover! 

Spider-Man Homage Cover by Mark Yoon and Anthony George

24x36 inch Retailer Poster as part of Retailer Pack Tier

PLUS ONE LUCKY FAN WILL WIN THIS COVER AT THE END OF THE CAMPAIGN! BACKER # WILL BE PULLED FROM RANDOMIZER! 

STRETCH GOALS:

$5,000 - Trading card for all backers. 

$10,000 - 6x9 print for all backers. 

$15,000 - Sticker for all backers. 

$20,000 - A pin-up section will be added to the book.

$25,000 - Artist Mark Yoon will sign all Vol. 1 Reprint Books.

story:
Piccolo Sommario

Ne storyboard o schizzi. Per Stefano Ricci, il racconto e il disegno  si costruiscono facendoli.. Poi, dopo prove cambiamenti, passi indietro, la storia si cristallizza "E' come la fine di un solitario, improvvisamente, tutto diventa veloce”. 

Così, La storia dell’Orso - 430 pagine - ha preso la sua forma nell'estate del 2013, appena un’anno fa



E' il 2007, quando la stampa ha raccontato la morte di Bruno, l'orso che si trovava nel nord Italia e ucciso su ordine delle autorità tedesche ha provocato un caso a Bruxelles.



Leggendo sui quotidiani, la notizia della caccia all'orso selvaggio, Stefano Ricci ha avuto l'idea di usarla come filo conduttore della sua storia. Per mettere in scena le testimonianze che ha raccolto si lancia in uno stupefacente road trip. Un'opera monumentale con immagini dense e ipnotiche.


Stefano Ricci, mentre faceva il servizio civile sulle ambulanze, scriveva quasi ogni giorno al suo amore, Anke, soprannominata Stellina. Egli descrive i suoi giorni, viaggi, paesaggi attraversati dalle stagioni che passano. E' come un diario. Le racconta anche i suoi sogni notturni, in cui la sua vita quotidiana e ricordi, recenti o dell’infanzia costituiscono un nuovo gioco, che ospitano il padre, la madre, lo zio, e Anke. 

Disegna delle storie. La sua dove egli si traspone in Stefano coniglio e il paramedico autista Renzo, in una scimmia. Vi è anche la storia di Bruno, l'orso selvatico ferito da un cacciatore che viene salvato da una ragazza (Anke) e da un cinghiale. Scoprendolo quasi morto vicino a una linea ferroviaria, avvertono il loro amico Manfred. Quest’ultimo si occupa di cinghiali da quasi 20 anni; capisce la loro lingua (Manfred è stato ispirato da Heinz Meynhardt che effettivamente ha studiato i cinghiali). Manfred racconta a Bruno, le sue esperienze dopo la caduta del muro di Berlino quando aveva 22 anni. E’ la fine della DDR, la ex Germania dell'Est, e gli inizi del capitalismo. E quella del meccanico che ripara la sua ambulanza, e si ricorda della sua vita nell'Aeronautica Militare Italiana durante la Seconda Guerra Mondiale. E anche quella del padre cacciatore che ha ferito Bruno, dal sinistro passato fascista. Queste ultime due storie basate su storie di famiglia dell’autore ... Storie umane e animali che si intersecano, che hanno in comune la peculiarità di cambiare a seconda del loro peregrinare.



L'Histoire de l'Ours  è uscita nel gennaio 2013 in Francia per Futuropolis. Il volume in soli due mesi ha scalato le classifiche del settore ponendosi al 1° posto come miglior storia a fumetti dell'inizio dell'anno! Con queste premesse abbiamo deciso di stampare l'edizione italiana de La storia dell’Orso con Quotlibet che si occupa di pubblicare e distribuire il volume e con il nostro lavoro e il vostro sostegno cercheremo di coprire i costi di stampa.

Per l'occasione Squadro Stamperia d'Arte di Bologna ha prodotto una nuova serigrafia formato 50x70 centimetri stampata il tiratura limitata firmata e numerata dall'autore.


"Sacchetto"

La serigrafia "Sacchetto", la locandina di Squadro disegnata da Ricci, il libro con dedica e il libro con disegno originale dedicato sono gli "omaggi" che mettiamo a disposizione per finanziare questo progetto. 


"Locandina"


Potete sostenerci attraverso le donazioni qui a destra, in cambio di una o più ricompense. Le spedizioni in Italia sono gratuite. La consegna è prevista entro il 30 dicembre 2014.

Grazie!
